title: HW3 Q1
content: Problem context: this problem builds directly on discussion and lecture. It has you recapitulate things that you've seen in lecture, but they're important and you should internalize them. Consequently, we recommend you try to do this without constantly looking at the lecture. This needs to be in your head.
document: Problem context: this problem builds directly on discussion and lecture. It has you recapitulate things that you've seen in lecture, but they're important and you should internalize them. Consequently, we recommend you try to do this without constantly looking at the lecture. This needs to be in your head.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Just a quick clarification on part b: if we take the element wise sign of the outer product xi*gi^t we get a matrix of shape (d1, d2), but xi is of shape (d1, 1), so how can we left-multiply xi by that matrix? Aren't the dimensions incompatible? (d1, d2) X (d1, 1)? <break/><break/>Perhaps the outer product should be gi*xi^T to match the shape of W and make the left-multiply dimensionally compatible?</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Just a quick clarification on part b: if we take the element wise sign of the outer product xi*gi^t we get a matrix of shape (d1, d2), but xi is of shape (d1, 1), so how can we left-multiply xi by that matrix? Aren't the dimensions incompatible? (d1, d2) X (d1, 1)? 

Perhaps the outer product should be gi*xi^T to match the shape of W and make the left-multiply dimensionally compatible?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, good catch. The correct equation should be y' = sign(gx^T)x.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Yes, good catch. The correct equation should be y' = sign(gx^T)x.
